data.text: Bicycle Dynamo Hub Phone Charging is So Slow

Dyno hub question. I have a Scmidt dyno hub. Recently bought a Kemo box to handle charging devices. All works fine, lights good and the bows LED lights up when on USB mode and I can hear the phone beep to say charging has started. But.... I did a little test ride Saturday, and over 4.5 hours of cycling about 22kph my phone went from 22% to 46%. This seems very slow charging. Or is it normal for dyno hub phone charging? Thanks
Unrelated/related. I have discovered that, when using solar panels, you must charge to the battery bank, then (later?) charge your device. Maybe your dyno hub is the same?
data.author: Gary Roberts

data.text: Hi Stewart, I have had a Schmitt dynohub for over a decade now. I usually use it for light (Edelux) but I have used it for phone charging through a 'sinewave' box quite successfully. I've never had any problems, but I'm very realistic regarding the phone charging. My phone has a 10,000mAh battery, so a 10% increase in charge over a few hours cycling is good. It depends on you phone's battery capacity as to how good an increase from 22 to 46% actually is. To muddy the waters further, it also depends whether you actually use the phone whilst you are riding, for example map/gps. In the past, I've been happy with drawing even over a day's touring - if I start the day with say 50% battery capacity, use the phone all day for gps/map and finish the day with 50%, then that's a win for me. Maybe I'm not cycling fast enough! Hope this helps, I wouldn't get too hung up on % figures.
data.author: Alistair Watt

data.text: The Forumslader.de and Cinq Plug are the most efficient generators when used with son hub. Check Fahrradzukunft.de in German for real world comparisons.
data.author: Supp Suppinger

data.text: Not sure what kind of phone you have, so just using some references. A Schmidt dyno hub only produces 3 watts. The new iPhones come with an 18 watt charger. My Motorola uses a 10 watt charger for fast charging. So even without the lights on, I would expect slow charging. If you have the lights on, I'd be surprised if you did any better than just keeping the phone from discharging. With battery capacities increasing on phones and higher wattage chargers used to facilitate faster charging, I've given up on charging my phone with my bike and just carry a big battery pack as I get several charges out of it before I need to find a place to plug it in overnight.
data.author: Tom Chandler

data.text: StVZO compliant dynamos need to be able to produce 3 W at 15 km/h. That doesn't mean that they can't produce more, especially at higher speeds. The Kemo is a pretty lousy USB-charger though, the only thing worse is the USB-Werk. The Kemo will produce about 2.3 W at 20 km/h on a SON 28 dynamo. Better chargers can deliver 4 W at the same speed.

data.text:
The problem with the USB Werk is that it's output is capped at 2.5 W. So no matter how fast you go, it will never produce more than 2.5 W. The German web magazine Fahrradzukunft (Bicycle Future) does regular tests of USB chargers for dynamos. Their latest test can be found here: https://fahrradzukunft.de/30/steckdose-unterwegs-8 The publication is in German only though, so you'd probably need to run the article through an online translator. According to Fahrradzukunft, the performance crown is held by a device called the Forumslader. I currently use the Cycle2Charge V3, which seems to offer the best bang for the bucks.

data.text:
Sounds like everything is working as it should in your setup. Getting a higher quality USB charger may boost performance by 10-15%, but nothing major. The main bottleneck is that dynamo hubs are designed around 20+-year-old power standards made for lights, not USB devices. If you're looking for a more powerful charging solution then pedalcell.com may be worth checking out. Full disclosure I'm one of the founders and happy to answer any questions
